description:
* Fixed Ramses particle ages and added deposit methods

* Optimized the age method

* Removed message for when particle_age doesn't exist

Tested with my existing RAMSES datasets. Load time is considerably longer now for these datasets, but now the current_time and stellar ages are correct. Did brief tests with Gadget datasets.
title: Fixing Ramses time values

content.raw:
In general you want to avoid bare `except`, here's a StackOverflow discussion that summarizes why it's a bad idea: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21553327/why-is-except-pass-a-bad-programming-practice

Also it's idiomatic to use `pass` if you want a block of code to do nothing, not `None`.
content.html:
In general you want to avoid bare except, here's a StackOverflow discussion that summarizes why it's a bad idea: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21553327/why-is-except-pass-a-bad-programming-practice

Also it's idiomatic to use pass if you want a block of code to do nothing, not None.

content.raw:
Looks tidier than my attempt https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/pull-requests/1644/bugfix-wip-setting-particle_age-in-ramses/diff. I will give it a test sometime soon.

Additionally, I think it might be a good idea to store the RAMSES conformal time data somewhere (was what I attempted in my pull request). Just my opinion. Looks good though.

content.raw: Could all the changes in this file be written in Cython? That is what I was attempting to do here https://bitbucket.org/cosmosquark/yt-time/src/094475195cb2d1016038b49c22048d91186ea227/yt/frontends/ramses/tform.pyx?fileviewer=file-view-default. It would considerably reduce the load time especially since these functions only really need to be preformed once.

content.raw: This actually seems to be because of random corruption generated by h5py. This happens every so often, it might be due to intermittent hardware failure on the text box or a bug in hdf5 or h5py. No one has spent the time to dig into it carefully yet. It's definitely unrelated to this PR but just to ease our minds I've triggered another test :)

content.raw:
Hey Mark,

I just did a pass over this pull request. I've made a couple commits on top of yours and Ben's which you can pull from me and incorporate into the PR with the following commands:

```
$ hg pull -B correct_ramses_ages https://bitbucket.org/ngoldbaum/yt
$ hg update correct_ramses_ages
$ python setup.py develop
```

Verify that my changes are ok - I removed the autogenerated C file that Ben mistakenly added and I also I made it so that your new deposit fields are deposited from the 'age' field, which is a name for particle ages that is being used in other frontends already. In addition, I've given ramses an alias from 'particle_age' to 'age', so you should still be able to access the new deposit fields form Ramses.

Once you've verified everything is ok, push the `correct_ramses_ages` bookmark to your fork.

Besides that, this PR is awesome! I'm very glad that we've resolved these long-standing issues with particle ages in ramses.
content.html:
Hey Mark,

I just did a pass over this pull request. I've made a couple commits on top of yours and Ben's which you can pull from me and incorporate into the PR with the following commands:

$ hg pull -B correct_ramses_ages https://bitbucket.org/ngoldbaum/yt
$ hg update correct_ramses_ages
$ python setup.py develop

Verify that my changes are ok - I removed the autogenerated C file that Ben mistakenly added and I also I made it so that your new deposit fields are deposited from the 'age' field, which is a name for particle ages that is being used in other frontends already. In addition, I've given ramses an alias from 'particle_age' to 'age', so you should still be able to access the new deposit fields form Ramses.

Once you've verified everything is ok, push the correct_ramses_ages bookmark to your fork.

Besides that, this PR is awesome! I'm very glad that we've resolved these long-standing issues with particle ages in ramses.

content.raw: I think there may still be a way to vectorize the age calculation in frontends/ramses/io.py now that it doesn't have a conditional. Any ideas on this?
content.html: I think there may still be a way to vectorize the age calculation in frontends/ramses/io.py now that it doesn't have a conditional. Any ideas on this?

content.raw:
Currently alpha in friedman in cosmology_time.pyx sets the accuracy of the method. I was thinking we could add this as a conditional parameter to the load call, but really the accuracy is better than a Myr, which is probably fine. Also, the import is quick enough now, I could increase the default alpha value as well.

Also, I think there may be a way to vectorize the age calculation in frontends/ramses/io.py now that it doesn't have a conditional. Any ideas on this?
content.html:
Currently alpha in friedman in cosmology_time.pyx sets the accuracy of the method. I was thinking we could add this as a conditional parameter to the load call, but really the accuracy is better than a Myr, which is probably fine. Also, the import is quick enough now, I could increase the default alpha value as well.

Also, I think there may be a way to vectorize the age calculation in frontends/ramses/io.py now that it doesn't have a conditional. Any ideas on this?
